column1: #comment: "This mapping was created following and expanding upon the SSSOM guidance: https://mapping-commons.github.io/sssom/spec/"

column7: Comments
SWEET does not have a definition.  This could change to exactMatch if SWEET adopted the ENVO definition.
SWEET does not have a definition or specific class for wind transport of snow.
Alpine ecosystem in ENVO is closely allied to the SWEET cryospheric realm AlpineTundra; but somewhat different from the Alpine tundra biome
Alpine ecosystem in ENVO is closely allied to the SWEET cryospheric realm AlpineTundra; but somewhat different from the Alpine tundra biome
SWEET Calf is less specific than ENVO anchored ice calf
SWEET needs to adjust the ENVO related to be this one.  In ENVO seasonal ice is associated with an area where it will melt, rather than an area where it will persist to become 2nd year ice
SWEET has two terms for snow cover (a thickness and a hydrospheric phenomenon);
Within ENVO it's a site in SWEET a realm hence related match.

In SWEET an arete is considered to be a type of plain, but in ENVO and in actuality an arete is a kind of ridge; so the SWEET hierarchy needs to be changed.  It should be noted that SWEET has 3 kinds of ridge; the closest is sorealo:Ridge.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term.
In SWEET a snowslide is a subclass of avalanche
Candidate Exact/Close match if SWEET updates the defintion and or hierachical placement. In ENVO it's a snowstorm that includes snow fall. In SWEET it's a snowfall.
Candidate Exact match if SWEET adopts the ENVO definition.

column2: calving of ice from an iceberg
column7: SWEET lacks more specific terms under ice calving
SWEET lacks more specific terms under ice calving
SWEET lacks more specific terms under ice calving
In SWEET this is a subclass of plain, but actually it is a roughly circular depression at the peak (which is a comment in SWEET), so the SWEET Heirarchy should be updated.
In SWEET this is a subclass of plain, but actually it is a roughly circular depression at the peak (which is a comment in SWEET), so the SWEET Heirarchy should be updated.
SWEET class is a mathmatical abstraction of a front, so related not candidate for exact.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET has no definition but the term is placed under the phenomenon heirarchy which is the equivalent of ENVO's processes
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
In SWEET this in a classification scheme (a categorical datatype with value Cryosol), not a physical entity as it is represented in ENVO

In SWEET this is a realm, while in ENVO it is an astronomical body part, so these are pretty close, however as per the subclassing of hydrosphere in SWEET this can't be a close match with the ENVO term which doesn't imply water.
Forced to be related as per the subclassing of hydrosphere in SWEET.
Snow cover is a process in SWEET which is loosely related to the concept of depth of snow in ENVO
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET DriftIce is less specific than ENVO's drifting sea ice mass
Englacial is a process in SWEET and in ENVO. A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term.
Candidate Exact match.  In SWEET this is deprecated.
SWEET doesn't have this level of granularity
In SWEET an esker is a glacial landform - a type of geometrical object, as are ridges but the two terms are parallel concepts; in ENVO an esker is a kind of ridge and a material entity.
SWEET has confounded the material with the process (double inheritance)
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term

SWEET has it as subclass to ice crystal which is probably not correct with the definition of firn we've come across. This could be refined in SWEET. If it is put as a subclass of snow it would be a candidate exact match.
This SWEET term maps even more closely to ENVO area of seasonal sea ice
SWEET considers fjords to be a subtype of estuary - ENVO doesn't.
SWEET doesn't have this level of granularity and limits leads to sea ice though fresh water ice can have leads as well (e.g., Great Lakes ice)
SWEET Calf is less specific than ENVO floating ice calf
ENVO Frazil is the needle-like crystals in suspension which may become frazil ice upon congelation.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
In SWEET FreezingFog is a Phenonena; while in ENVO it is an environmental material .
In ENVO we have the process and the object resulting from it the latter here, in SWEET it's the object resulting from the process.

In ENVO this is a process while in SWEET it is a type of Atmospheric precipitation which is a phenomenon which likely means process but this isn't guaranteed. SWEET would need to seperate their phenonma hierarchy into phenomenal vs processes.
Holds regardless if parent is exact or close.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET refers to a process, ENVO a landform
An environmental material in ENVO but a geometric object in SWEET.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET doesn't have this level of granularity
In SWEET this in a classification scheme (a categorical datatype with value Gelisol), not a physical entity as it is represented in ENVO
Ablation zone is in the Cryospheric Realm of SWEET but it isn't clear exactly how that compares to the zones in ENVO where there is a hierarchy of zones
Accumulation zone is in the Cryospheric Realm of SWEET but it isn't clear exactly how that compares to the zones in ENVO where there is a hierarchy of zones
This is the process of ice gain in glaciers
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET aggregates several processes operating at different levels.  SWEET has close match to the ENVO term, but we aren't convinced
Glaciation in ENVO refers to the time period when glaciers are growing.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term. SWEET has this as exact match but is missing a definition.
SWEET's term here is a zone.  There is no related term in ENVO so we made a related match to ENVO's glacier.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
ENVO term is a mass, SWEET term is a region although both probably reffer to the same part of the glacier.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
Candidate Exact match. Placement in SWEET may need revision (mass noun vs countable entity).
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term

This mapping is between a role and material entity, important example of semantic clarification provided by more expressive ontology framework, (i.e., there is no material entity that is a greenhouse gas, however certain gasses can bear this greenhouse role).

Within ENVO this is a material within SWEET it's a phenonema which could be either a material or process. This could be separated out better within SWEET. Candidate for close match if the SWEET hierarchy is clarified.
Candidate Exact match. Depending on SWEET's placement of phenomena.
Candidate Exact match. Depending on SWEET's placement of phenomena.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term.
These are both processes.  A better mapping would be to ENVO's condensation process.
Mapped in SWEET to ENVO as close match. Possibly candidate exact match.
Accumulation is a process in SWEET while ENVO distinguishes types of accumulation
Ice calf is a mass of ice in ENVO while the SWEET Cryospheric Realm term calf can only apply to calves of ice.  A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET has no definition but the term is placed under the phenomenon heirarchy which is the equivalent of ENVO's processes

In ENVO ice cap is a type of ice mass; while in SWEET it is a realm. The notion of realm in SWEET and the way it's subclassed indicates that its top-level semantics need revision. An ice cap is not a realm, but part of a realm (probably).
In SWEET ice field is sea ice; whereas in ENVO an ice cap is just a planetary body part
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
In SWEET this is a Phenonena; while in ENVO it is an environmental material .

In SWEET a lead is a water substance while in ENVO it is a layer (SWEET appears to confound composition and morphology) - also SWEET restricts leads to sea ice; while there are clearly leads in navigatable fresh water (e.g., great lakes) - SWEET issue needed
A phenomenon in SWEEt and a process in ENVO.

Within SWEET this is subclassed to both ice (a material) and atmospheric precipitation which is a process. If this were just a material it woud be a candidate exact match to ENVO, however having both parents makes this mapping ambiguous.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
Related as the ENVO class is more generic; the SWEET class is specifically a planetary bounding layer.
In SWEET this is a 3-D geospatial entity, instead of ENVO's environmental material.
A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term
SWEET lacks more specific terms under ice calving

In ENVO this is a process while in SWEET it is a type of Atmospheric precipitation which is a phenomenon (which is ambiguous). The relations between the two term's superclass is what leads us to say related instead of close.
In SWEET a kame is a glacial landform - a type of geometrical object; in ENVO a kame is a kind of material entity.
Candidate Exact match. SWEET needs a definition and depending on what that becomes this could become exact match
Candidate Exact match. In SWEET there is a long comment which should be turned into a definition.  SWEET talks about snow bands not the snow itself.
Candidate Exact match. SWEET needs a definition and depending on what that becomes this could become exact match
The SWEET definition is limited to the Earth while much of that text is a comment in ENVO and ENVO isn't scoped to the Earth
SWEET doesn't have this level of granularity
SWEET terms is broader as it includes all flows e.g. energy
Assuming subclasses of change in SWEET are processes (BFO process) but some terms in the hierarchy are debatable
SWEET hierarchy looks to be a process like in ENVO's. A candidate for exact match if SWEET adds ENVO's definition to SWEET's term.
ENVO term's parent is close match.
The ENVO term is a process; while in SWEETs system phenomena covers several things quality or process.
Relationship is unclear. The SWEET hierarchy doesn't specify what's transported can't tell if it's material or not.

In SWEET the parent class is a realm, while in ENVO it is an astronomical body part, so the SWEET term is broader than the ENVO term.
We can have equitorial tundra (based on elevation) hence a broad match here.
Supports interoperbility for terms like precipitation of sleet which is cryo relevant.

Related as the ENVO superclass is more generic, including more kinds of ice than just water ice.  The SWEET class is specifically a planetary bounding layer.  It is not clear whether SWEET term includes more than water ice, thus we keep this and the mapping to ENVO ice surface layer.
